intro: Quercus foemina, commonly known as the dwarf chestnut oak, is a deciduous tree native to the southeastern United States. It typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters, featuring a rounded crown and thick, fissured bark. The leaves are alternate, simple, and lobed, with a dark green upper surface and a lighter underside. Its acorns are small, oblong, and often have a shallow cupule, maturing in one growing season. This species is adapted to moist, well-drained soils and thrives in partial to full sunlight.
